pr_title: Allow nesting CONTAIN predicates with and/or

timeline.bodyText:
This would fail the test
assertEquals(3, g.V().or(__.has("id", P.within(2, 3, 4)), __.has("id", P.within())).count().next());
timeline.author: li-boxuan

replies.bodyText:
Thanks for the review. Basically needed to change two lines within the definition of OR to catch that bug. I updated the branch by pushing a separate commit containing the fix so it is easier to review.
Also added 14 new test cases which cover all of the empty argument cases as well as some previously untested combinations of with and without cases. If you can find different combinations worth testing, please let me know.
replies.author: rngcntr

timeline.message:
Fix broken logic for or() constraints in QueryUtil

Signed-off-by: Florian Grieskamp <florian.grieskamp@gdata.de>

timeline.bodyText:
I wonder if there is any performance difference between:
OR(NOT_EQUAL(x) AND NOT_EQUAL(y))
v.s.
OR(NOT_EQUAL(x)) OR(NOT_EQUAL(y))?
timeline.author: li-boxuan

replies.bodyText: I don't quite get your point here. It looks like your second case is missing a logical operator between the two ORs. Anyway, I can't spot what kind of possible change in the code you refer to, in order to create one or the other of your examples.
replies.author: rngcntr

replies.bodyText: Oh never mind, I got it wrong
replies.author: li-boxuan

timeline.bodyText: I understand they are semantically the same, but will there be a performance difference (even if very little)?
timeline.author: li-boxuan

replies.bodyText: There may be a little difference in performance, but the empty and actually serves a functional purpose. Otherwise the surrounding or can be empty which results in or() being evaluated as false instead of or(and()) which is true.
replies.author: rngcntr

timeline.bodyText: nitpick: it took me a while to understand the comment. I guess you mean "Handle unsatisfiable condition or(within()) like it does not exist"
timeline.author: li-boxuan

replies.bodyText: It was actually meant to say "Handle any unsatisfiable condition within an OR statement like it does not exist."
replies.author: rngcntr
